JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;George Nicolaou;Lech Garlicki;Nebojša Vučinić;Päivi Hirvelä;Vincent A. De Gaetano;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . She is represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON ORG , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , Mr PERSON of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
On DATE the applicant arrived in GPE with a tourist visa valid for DATE . She had not applied for a residence permit beforehand in GPE before arriving in GPE .
On DATE the applicant applied for a residence permit in GPE on the basis of family ties .
On DATE ORG ( ORG virasto , PERSON ) rejected her application and ordered her removal to GPE .

On DATE the applicant appealed to ORG ( hallinto - oikeus , förvaltningsdomstolen ) , asking that the decision of ORG be quashed and that she be granted a residence permit . She claimed that she could no longer take care of herself and was thus dependent on her family ’s help . Her apartment in GPE was situated on the CARDINALth floor and the lift was often out of order . She could not climb the stairs without help and even with help it was difficult for her to walk . She could not walk outside without help . She had a gas stove in her apartment which was dangerous because of her memory problems . All her relatives lived in GPE . Her husband had died in DATE in GPE . He was an ORG who had applied for a residence permit in GPE on that ground but the application had lapsed when he died . The applicant had CARDINAL child , a daughter PERSON , who had lived in GPE for DATE . She had obtained NORP citizenship in DATE on the basis of her NORP descent .

On DATE ORG rejected the applicant ’s appeal . It found that the applicant could not be regarded as the family member of ORG The applicant suffered from toxic goitre , Parkinson ’s disease , hypertension and memory problems and she had had a mild stroke . She could not live alone nor manage her medication . The family life between the applicant and her daughter had been interrupted in DATE when the latter moved to GPE . After DATE it was no longer possible for them to continue family life . The applicant was not fully dependent on her daughter as she had a possibility to receive treatment in her home country . Even considered as a whole , it was not unreasonable to refuse the applicant a residence permit on the basis of her health or the lack of family ties .
On an unspecified date the applicant appealed to ORG ( korkein hallinto - oikeus , högsta förvaltnings - domstolen ) , reiterating the grounds of appeal already presented before ORG .
On DATE ORG refused the applicant leave to appeal .
Already on DATE the applicant lodged another application for a residence permit on the basis of family ties .

On DATE ORG rejected this second application and again ordered her removal to GPE . The ORG found , in addition to what had already been stated in ORG decision of CARDINAL DATE , that the applicant ’s husband had died in DATE and she had no close relatives in GPE . Her daughter had lived in GPE since DATE . According to the medical certificates submitted to the ORG , the applicant suffered , in addition to those conditions mentioned already in ORG decision , from panic attacks . Moreover , an operation was envisaged for the removal of the toxic goitre but it was not known whether it had taken place . The applicant had a close relationship with her daughter in GPE who could help her financially in arranging necessary care and treatment in GPE . The daughter could also visit her mother there . It was thus not unreasonable to refuse the applicant a residence permit on the basis of her health or the lack of family ties .
The applicant did not appeal against this decision to ORG .
